data.text: Contents
Introduction

In March 2020 new guidance was issued – ‘Guidance on using shielding on patients for diagnostic radiology applications'. This terminology refers to radiation protection applied directly to patients undergoing diagnostic and interventional X-ray procedures within the healthcare sector, hereafter referred to as patient contact shielding. It does not include shielding built into the imaging equipment or in the room design and excludes ad hoc protection not actually placed on the patient (e.g. the use of shielding on incubators in neonatal intensive care units, as it does not touch the baby).

This guidance is based on current understanding of organ radiosensitivity (for example testes are no longer listed as a radiosensitive organ for cancer incidence) and heritable effects associated with typical dose ranges which are likely to be negligible. It is also not possible to limit internal scatter (especially for ovaries). The potential harm (risk of cancer) is considered very low and though shielding may reduce patient dose in certain areas the risk of movement of the shielding / misplacement leads to a likelihood of repeat imaging.

It is important that the application of patient contact shielding, if required, should only take place once all other dose reduction techniques (e.g. selection of exposure factors, collimation) have been applied.

Even outside the primary radiation beam (referred to as ‘out of plane' in the BIR guidance), efforts spent on correct positioning and optimising protocol parameters can lead to dose savings which are more significant than applying patient contact shielding.

Overall recent findings suggest that contact shielding provides minimal or no benefit and professionals should concentrate on other areas of radiation protection which are more effective in optimising the patient radiation exposure.

The use of shielding in diagnostic imaging should be guided by the supporting evidence and the focus should be on what is safest for the patient, however in almost all scenarios the use of patient contact shielding is not recommended.
This guidance is based on updated research and practice.
This document sets out a summary of this guidance for Radiology applications but if staff are unsure they should read the full guidance on the BIR website or contact the diagnostic MPE for advice.
This follows the IRMER17 regulations requirement to keep exposures As Low As Reasonably Practicable.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to provide guidance on the use of patient contact shielding for Radiology applications
Definitions

table_items.text: Shielding placed on patients to protect vulnerable areas from the effects of ionising radiation (generally lead rubber or equivalent)

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Local Radiology Governance Groups Duties Are:

Local Radiology Governance Groups – Are responsible for the local level implementation, adherence and monitoring of this Guidance as well as it's communication to wider stakeholders where required. These groups are also responsible for ensuring that any amendments required are communicated to the author in a timely manner for document revision.
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive)
Managers of Radiology services – must ensure that this guidance is made available and communicated to their teams and that their teams have adequate training in these matters.
Radiology Operators and Practitioners, Radiographers, Radiology Nurses and radiology assistants – must abide by the guidance outlined in section 5 below.
Patient contact shielding procedure
Patient contact shielding should not be applied in almost all circumstances.
Ensure you communicate with and provide adequate information to patients regarding appropriate use of shielding (see Appendix 4).

Note every individual has a right to request or refuse shielding and should be supported to make their own decision. If contact shielding is used at the patient's request, this should be documented on the RIS system.
If an individual is anxious take time to explain the overarching dose reduction strategy
The priority is to obtain a suitable diagnostic image, where benefit outweighs risk. Each decision to use shielding should be relevant to the individual circumstances.

A few exceptions have been identified These may occur where a particular patient care pathway requires a number of repeat examinations where patient contact shielding may be applied, particularly in the case of paediatric patients.
Repeat procedures due to use of patient contact shielding should be investigated using local procedures – i.e. an entry on Datix and an investigation by the RPS.
In the case of significant exposures staff must ensure the Duty of Candour requirements are met.
Consent

The patient must give permission before the placement of patient contact shielding. In the rare circumstances when patient contact shielding is justified, the patient must be fully informed and provided with adequate information regarding the benefits and risks of using the contact shielding to enable them to make a choice. If required contact the diagnostic MPE for advice.
Applying patient contact shielding
Some practical issues to consider where shielding has been justified:

With paediatric patients it may be more difficult to ensure that the contact shielding remains out of the primary beam, due to patient size and risk of movement. The use of shielding in children should reflect best practice and should take into account the responsibilities of operators and if required be discussed with the diagnostic MPE. Inappropriate or inaccurate use of patient contact shielding is part of the local reject analysis.
Staff must know the process for when repeat exposures are required due to misplacement of shielding.
Staff must know how to store and maintain patient contact shielding. It should either be kept on dedicated hangers or stored flat (without creases).

Where required staff must have a range of patient contact shielding and suitable storage facilities – but this may only be appropriate at larger centres considering recommendations that it should not generally be used.
Diagnostic radiology
For diagnostic Radiology

table_items.text: Patient contact shielding for protection of gonads and pelvic region

Anticipate very few specific situations where this does not apply. May be considered for male adult and paediatric patients requiring imaging where gonads are less than 5 cm from the edge of primary beam. Female adult and paediatric patients: Not recommended for imaging in the pelvic region due to obscuring diagnostic information or to interfere with AEC function
Patient contact shielding for protection of breast
Use PA positioning rather than shielding for spinal and chest examinations where possible If using AP projection then a Scoliosis shawl may be considered
Patient contact shielding for protection of eye lens
Use PA skull positioning, no recommendations for shielding.

Not required for examinations outside the pelvic / abdominal region (diaphragm to knee). For examinations within pelvic region, consider non-ionising imaging alternatives. If ionising radiation must be used carry out a thorough justification and risk assessment process. This risk assessment should be based
upon risk vs benefit to the patient.

data.text: Use of AEC

Should a patient contact shielding device obscure an active AEC device, there is the likely risk that this will significantly increase the radiation dose to the patient. Care should be taken where patient contact shielding is used to ensure that it does not encroach in any way on the AEC system. If there is a risk of this happening then patient contact shielding must not be used.
Pregnant patients

Patient contact shielding is not recommended for pregnant patients, however it has been documented that pregnant patients undergoing diagnostic radiology examinations may request patient contact shielding despite undergoing an examination outside the pelvic region and not usually requiring extra protection. In these cases whether or not to provide extra shielding, usually in the form of lead/lead equivalent material draped over the abdomen, is not recommended but is at the discretion of the radiographer. The local rules can be checked for guidance or the RPS can be contacted for advice. Of course, in such cases accurate collimation must be used and the shielding must not encroach on the AEC system.
Diagnostic and interventional fluoroscopy

table_items.text: Patient contact shielding during fluoroscopy procedures

No radiation protective shielding should be routinely applied to patients undergoing a fluoroscopic examination. Great care should also be taken if protective material, intended to reduce staff radiation dose, is applied to patients.

data.text: Shielding in CT

The use of patient contact shielding is not recommended for CT for the majority of imaging situations (see section 9.7 of the BIR guidance). Where patient contact shielding is being considered, the guidance in the BIR guidance chapters should be taken into account.

table_items.text: In-plane (in the primary beam) organ contact shielding (adult and children) including lenses of the eye.
Not recommended Ensure optimisation by alternative means wherever practicable.
Adverse effects on image quality Unpredictable AEC performance - rendering it ineffective, or even resulting in higher dose . Often low dose protocols can achieve the required diagnostic
outcome In-plane contact shielding of the Gonads is not recommended due to adverse effects on imaging quality.
Out-of-plane (outside of the primary beam) organ contact shielding (adult and children) Or Out-of-plane contact shielding to protect foetus in pregnancy

Actual dose savings will be low. Not possible to limit internal scatter. Highest savings when shield close to edge of the scanning volume but more likely to interfere with AEC if close An adequate distance to rule out misplacement or movement of protection then renders the reduction in external scatter minimal.

data.text: Mammography
The use of patient contact shielding is not recommended for mammography

table_items.text: No radiation protective shielding should be routinely applied to patients undergoing a mammographic examination

data.text: Shielding in dental radiography
The use of patient contact shielding is not recommended for dental radiography except for large FOV Dental CBCT units when the diagnostic MPE should be consulted.

table_items.text: Eyes should not be in the primary beam. Not possible to shield the other organs such as the brain, salivary gland and lens of the eye without obscuring required anatomy
All European guidance regarding good practice should be followed. Use of rectangular collimation, beam aiming devices, film/detector speed and paralleling technique to be used first.
Not recommended with the exception of large FOV units, where there may be some benefit. In which case it is recommended that the MPE is consulted.

Insufficient evidence for small field of view but effectiveness of a thyroid shield is likely to be low due to the exclusion of the thyroid from the primary beam and the reduction in secondary radiation from tighter collimation. The use of a thyroid collar may lead to artefacts in the images. An MPE should be consulted where the use of a thyroid collar is to be considered, such as units with a large FOV.

For intraoral radiography, use of the parallel technique is recommended. If X-ray beam MUST be directed towards the abdomen then patient contact shielding (e.g. lead apron) covering the abdomen could be considered for psychological purposes of reassurance as unlikely to be detrimental to the diagnostic quality of the images.

data.text: Training requirements

No specific training requirements, other than knowledge and understanding of this guidance. However staff must have a good understanding of the risks and benefits of patient contact shielding and be able to explain this to patients, and know what to do when patients either demand or refuse patient contact shielding.

References
Appendix 1: To consider when communicating benefit and risk
When communicating the benefit and risk of using patient contact shielding the following points should be considered:

Is it safe to delay the examination if the patient is still insisting on the use of patient contact shielding contrary to advice? Is the patient likely to be significantly reassured if patient contact shielding is used, even if it is unlikely to afford them any radiation protection? (N.B. it is not recommended that patient contact shielding is used as a means of reassurance. This should be addressed through appropriate one to one communication.)

The specific needs of paediatric patients should be taken into consideration and techniques used to aid communication and nurture confidence (for example play specialists and distraction techniques). The use of patient contact shielding, where indicated, must be the final step in an overarching optimisation strategy.
